I'll never forget the day I realized I was uncool - or at least, that's what my mind kept telling me. It started with little things, like how my friends would tease me about my love for old movies, or how I'd get laughed at during lunch for wearing the same outfit three days in a row (okay, maybe four). But it wasn't until we went to the school dance and I accidentally spilled punch all over my favorite band t-shirt that I knew I was truly uncool.

As I stood there, watching my friends laugh and take selfies with the ruined shirt, I felt this crushing sense of inadequacy wash over me. Why couldn't I just be more popular? More fashionable? More... cool? My mind began racing with all the ways I was failing, all the ways I was disappointing those around me. I thought about how my parents must be so disappointed in me too, how they must have always known I was destined for mediocrity.

It's funny, because looking back, I realize that I've been calling myself uncool for years now. Ever since freshman year, when I got lost on the way to my first period class and ended up in the wrong classroom. Or when I tried out for the school play and didn't make it. Or even when I wore those ridiculous plaid pants to the cafeteria and everyone stared at me. Yeah, I'm pretty much the epitome of uncoolness.

Sometimes I wonder if anyone else feels this way, trapped in their own private hell of self-doubt and inadequacy. Do other people feel like they're just pretending to be something they're not, like they're living a lie? I guess only they know for sure, but for me, it's hard to shake off the feeling that I'm just a fake, a pretender to the throne of coolness. And honestly, sometimes I wish I could just disappear into thin air, leaving behind the awkwardness and the embarrassment, and start fresh somewhere else. Somewhere where I can be myself, without fear of judgment or rejection.
